qas.question: Has the final been played by a two clubs outside of the top divisions?

answers.text: The final has never been contested by two teams from outside the top division

qas.question: Has the final been won by a club outside of the top divisions?

answers.text: there have only been eight winners who weren't in the top flight

qas.question: Who was the first outside club to win?
What year did that take place?
How many second tier have made the finals?

answers.text: only 24 finalists have come from outside English football's top tier

qas.question: How many winners have been in the top flight?
What team has never won the final?
How many finalists have come from inside English football's top tier?
What year did the first inside club win?
What was the last finalist from inside the top two tiers?

context: <a0_0>The final has never been contested by two teams from outside the top division<a0_0/> and <a1_0>there have only been <b5_0>eight<b5_0/> winners who weren't in the top flight<a1_0/>: <a2_0><b6_0>Notts County<b6_0/><a2_0/> (<a3_0><b8_0>1894<b8_0/><a3_0/>); Tottenham Hotspur (1901); Wolverhampton Wanderers (1908); Barnsley (1912); West Bromwich Albion (1931); Sunderland (1973), Southampton (1976) and West Ham United (1980). With the exception of Tottenham, these clubs were all playing in the second tier (the old Second Division) - Tottenham were playing in the Southern League and were only elected to the Football League in 1908, meaning they are the only non-league winners of the FA Cup. Other than Tottenham's victory, <a4_0>only <b7_0>24<b7_0/> finalists have come from outside English football's top tier<a4_0/>, with a record of 7 wins and 17 runners-up: and none at all from the third tier or lower, <b9_0>Southampton<b9_0/> (1902) being the last finalist from outside the top two tiers.
